description: Borrowed from Late Latin situātus, past participle of Medieval Latin situō (“to locate, place”), from Latin situs (“a site”).

adjectives.description: situate (comparative more situate, superlative most situate)

examples: Wadley in Berkshire is situate in a vale, though not so fertile a soil as some vales afford […].

verbs.description: situate (third-person singular simple present situates, present participle situating, simple past and past participle situated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To place on or into a physical location.
examples: The statue is situated in a corner hardly visible to the public, except through a window from an outside maintenance area situated behind the building.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To place or put into an intangible place or position, such as social, ethical, fictional, etc. Most commonly used adjectivally in past participle and often used figuratively.
examples: The mayor is situated between probable censure and possible recall.
